events.comment:
At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * (1 - speed)

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * (1 - speed)

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * (1 - speed)^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln((1 - speed)))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

parameters: TargetedRotationAngle + 90 + RotationAngleOffset + AngleDifference(CameraAngle(Object.Layer()), TargetedRotationAngle + 90 + RotationAngleOffset) * exp(TimeDelta() * RotationLogSpeed)
TargetedElevationAngle + ElevationAngleOffset + AngleDifference(90 - Scene3D::CameraRotationX(Object.Layer()), TargetedElevationAngle + ElevationAngleOffset) * exp(TimeDelta() * ElevationLogSpeed)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ParticleEmitter3D
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Display a large number of particles in 3D to create visual effects in a 3D game.
description: 3D particle emitters let you create and display many small particles to simulate visual effects in your game  like fire, explosions, smoke, or dust.

The parameters of the object can be configured in multiple different ways to create a specific desired effect. GDevelop will give a set of a pre-configured 3D particle emitters that you should try first.
Use these 3D particle emitters in 3D games. For 2D games or particles that appear on a game's 2D user interface, use the 2D particle emitter object instead.

changelog.breaking: - the object rotates the other way around X axis.
- Object properties for position and rotation have been removed. They must be set with the instance editor or the action.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
description: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
- Short shaking can be used to give impact (explosion, hit)
- Shaking can go indefinitely to set an ambiance (engine vibration, earthquake, pulsing)
- Low frequency shaking allows to simulate slow moving objects (ship rocking back and forth)
- No adaptation of the game events is needed.
- It fixes an issue when used with scrolling, the amplitude will feel bigger in this case.
- The shaking relies on noise which could feel a bit different.
- This extension can no longer do impulses. For this, another extension "Camera impulse" can be used.

n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MousePointerLock
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
description: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
For example, a user can rotate or continue to manipulate an object by moving the mouse endlessly ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://mouse-pointer-lock)).
Without the pointer lock, the rotation or operation will stop the moment the pointer reaches the edge of the browser or screen.
Game players don't have to worry about leaving the gameplay area or accidentally clicking on another application that moves the mouse focus away from the game.
Locking the pointer locks `CursorX()` and `CursorY()` expressions.

// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where

const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
